response.answer_text: Hypnosis is absolutely real, it is a natural state that we enter into at least twice a day, anytime we start to fall asleep or wake up, anytime we get fully engrossed in a movie to the extent we feel it is happening to us, while driving and we can’t recall our journey around that bend a few miles back or we miss our exit etc. all forms of natural hypnosis at work. There are literally hundreds of ways you can induce someone into a hypnotic trance, I’ve seen it done with objects, various forms of shock, written words on paper, arm raising techniques, and various other techniques, although some are more professional than others, some have better shock or wow value for street and stage work, and some are just similar variations along the same theme. There have been scientific studies, I forget where now, showing the change in the brain during hypnosis. Pretty much everyone can be hypnotized once you know their suggestibility type, are they an E or a P. A trained professional (super easy to learn basic hypnotic inductions, takes time to learn the more professional aspects and therapeutic uses) can use this natural state of hypnosis to bypass your critical factor, accessing your subconscious mind, and getting positive suggestions to go in and be accepted, but only if you are truly open to those positive suggestions in the first place. No one can fully control you with traditional hypnosis alone when you know you're being hypnotized, they may be able to catch you off guard or temporarily get you to do something minor that you don’t care about, such as with stage hypnosis and street hypnosis acts, but they can’t make you give them all your money or go shoot someone, unless that is something you are ok with doing normally in a waking state, or other factors are brought in to play, something you would not see in a professional Hypnotherapy practice. (See Derren Browns experiments all over YouTube, he gets some people to do all kinds of things using other techniques combined with hypnosis). Hypnosis is also excellent at helping people get rid of bad habits like smoking, as long as the person truly wants to quit smoking then they will, many Hypnotherapists have a high success rate with smoking cessation when done correctly. Obviously anyone who truly wishes to continue smoking and has no intention of quitting ever, cannot be made to quit through hypnosis, as they will always make that conscious choice to smoke again, which is why many Hypnotherapists won’t even see a client for a session unless they are coming in of their own free choice, and fully ready to quit smoking, not being coerced to come in by friends, family or their job. So, for anyone to say hypnosis does not exist or isn't real just because they haven't experienced it, would be like saying dreams don't exist just because you don't remember having one when you wake. (I'm sure there must be someone out there who never remembers their dreams). Plenty of evidence exists that hypnosis is real and has been around for a long time.

Hello! :) The following is my personal opinion and it is not intended to insult anyone in any possible way. I respect everyone’s opinion, but I also protect mine strongly. Ok here it goes - as someone who always tries his best to search for the truth regardless of whether his opinion is going to be popular or not, I am going to kind of go against the grain here and give you a very clear answer - NO. I am really surprised that every single answer so far has been positive despite the lack of real, well established, unambiguous, peer-reviewed scientific evidence. And, as much as I respect everyone’s opinion, I can’t help but get the impression that many people here believe in hypnosis because they want to believe in it and wish it was real, not because they truly believe in it. Correct me if I am wrong, I am not trying to be negative in any way. Proving that hypnosis is a legitimate phenomenon by supposedly making subjects fall asleep by snapping your fingers and then mind controlling them, is something I just can’t even take seriously. Think logically, if somebody’s words and finger snapping could somehow make you fall asleep and make you do things out of your control, don’t you think that people would abuse it all the time? Don’t you think that in your entire lifetime there would be some random situation where certain words are said and they would just happen to affect you and make you suddenly fall asleep? But those things never happen… I already hear someone shouting - “But it’s not about some random words and finger snapping, not everybody can say things just like that and hypnotize someone! Only a skilled hypnotist can do that!” - ok, so what exact sequence of words has to be said in order to somehow, miraculously, change one’s brain chemistry so that they start acting like a chicken or a dog without even being aware of it and in what pitch and pace a hypnotist has to pronounce that sequence of words to induce such a miraculous brain chemistry change?I.e. if not everybody can be a hypnotist, then what scientifically proven criteria you need to fulfill to be a hypnotist? We humans use science as the only way to prove the legitimacy of something, hence, if something cannot be scientifically proven, then it can’t be treated as a legitimate phenomenon. Sure, maybe people can’t directly prove that it doesn’t exist either, but as long as people can’t prove its existence, they should not include it in the scientific literature and regard it as a legitimate phenomenon. One is a belief, other is a proven phenomenon. For example sometimes I believe in some greater force (call it God or whatever you want), I really do a lot of times, but that’s a belief, and unless I prove it’s existence somehow I should not expect people to include that in the scientific literature and regard it as a truly legitimate and proven phenomenon, I can only keep that belief for myself. Also, we should never forget that even scientists make mistakes, and that not all scientific studies are truly legitimate, that’s why the best scientific studies are tested many times in many different situations by multiple teams of scientists. All in all, I am kind of disappointed that it’s 2016 and we still have debates about something as baseless and as fraudulent as hypnosis (as defined in the dictionary and as presented in the media). Again, I really didn’t mean to insult anyone, but I will regard hypnosis as such unless someone hypnotizes me successfully, which was never the case so far, or provides me with legitimate scientific information based on legitimate scientific experiments, clear from any taking out of context, ambiguity, result manipulations or media spins. Of course this all is referring to verbally induced hypnosis, I am not questioning the potential existence of a hypnotic state that is induced by drugs or by using some other physically mind-altering things such as TMS and similar. P.S. As for your friends from school making fun of you, I am totally on your side even though I disagree with your belief about hypnosis. I was made fun of many times in school for telling my friends that in Japan at that time robots were playing soccer (and that was obviously really true!) :) Just remember that if they are real friends they will have limits in “making fun of you” i.e. they will just joke around about it in a friendly and a playful manner and you should accept those jokes at your own expense and should laugh it all off together. However if they start making heavy fun of you in an unfriendly way, where it becomes like bullying, then you should know that, obviously, they are not your friends and you should just ignore them.

Let’s break this question down first. What is hypnosis? As practiced for the past hundred years or so, it’s a method of getting people to relax and “open up” to whatever it is they might see, hear or sense. Can everyone do that? Of course not, we’re all different, and many of us have a harder time at the “letting go” or “opening up” part. Doesn’t mean it doesn’t work, or that it couldn’t work, it just might be harder for a person to “go somewhere.” I had the impression that hypnosis was some kind of form of “knocking a person out” so that they were unconscious. That’s not the case at all - having filmed 45 people under deep hypnosis, having done 5 sessions myself, filming them and transcribing the experience, and examining thousands of hypnosis cases from Dr. Helen Wambach, Michael Newton and Dr. Brian Weiss from their books, hypnosis is a valid tool for a person to explore their subconscious. Doesn’t mean they’re going to get anywhere. Doesn’t mean that what they see or experience is valid, real or actually happened. However, like seeing a film, and then doing research on “what really happened” people who do hypnosis can explore avenues and areas that their conscious mind cannot. Hypnosis therapy has about around for thousands of years, the Egyptians had temples for it, and practitioners who put people into “dream like states” to explore the “afterlife.” Stage hypnosis, like a game of “playing with a person’s ability to follow suggestion” is something that’s very surface and does not resonate. In the case of deep hypnosis, four to six hour sessions that can be repeated over time, a person is able to access things from memory. Where is that memory if it doesn’t exist in the brain? As I’ve reported in “Flipside” and “It’s a Wonderful Afterlife” people under deep hypnosis claim to be able to access all kinds of information - not only about previous lifetimes, but the “between lives” arena where they claim we choose our next lifetime. They claim that we can access our experience doing so - examine previous lifetimes, examine why we chose those lifetimes, why we chose this lifetime and what they all have in common. It’s not a theory, belief or opinion people do these things - I’ve been filming them do so for ten years. It doesn’t matter what their background, upbringing, religious beliefs (or lack of them) have been - they all pretty much say the same things about the journey. So asking if hypnosis “works” is a bit like saying “does my car work?” Yes, it can work, and there are times that it can’t work. The function of the car is not the issue, it’s “how does a car run?” that is key, and “what is needed in order to make my car run?” The person driving the car isn’t the creator of the car, they’re just riding along in the seat and steering the car in a particular direction. In like form, there are good hypnotherapists who have driven the same roads before, and can help guide a person down those roads. But they are the ones who are “seeing” experiencing, “hearing” what they experience - the hypnotherapist is not. For example, I was speaking with someone on the BBC radio the other day and after our conversation, we decided to take a little trip - “while fully conscious.” He was not “under hypnosis” nor did I try to “put him under hypnosis.” I asked if he had any vivid memory of any person or event, that seemed other worldly. He recalled a fellow who worked for his father that “appeared” in his mind’s eye a few days before he died. He didn’t know this person well, hadn’t been thinking about him - but he had “appeared” in his mind’s eye and he never could understand why. So I asked him to focus on the memory - to “take a photo of it.” As he did that, we “walked up to the person” and asked him some questions. The fellow “answered” the questions much to the surprise of the person I was speaking with. In a few moments we were discussing a previous lifetime they had together, and he gave details about those events,location, etc. Further, we went and visited his “spiritual council” (no other term for it) where his guides and teachers gather to give him advice on his journey. The point is - he wasn’t under hypnosis, I wasn’t telling him what to see. He was seeing these things without my assistance, over a skype phone. One can argue that he was “making it all up” but the problem with that notion is that he was saying the EXACT SAME THINGS that thousands of others have said about their council, guide, why he chose that lifetime, etc. No hypnosis required or needed. Did these events occur? I leave it up to him to look up. In my books, I take the time to do as much forensic reserach as I can. Not everyone remembers things the same way - sometimes dates are off, names are skewed, or other details are fuzzy. But then I can’t remember what I had for breakfast yesterday - so the memory of previous lifetimes can often be faulty (as memory often is). But the overall takeaway from these experiences is that hypnosis can’t harm anyone - in some cases it can help people. I filmed one woman with severe Parkinson’s who stopped shaking during the entire session. For six hours she stopped her relentless shaking - only her finger bobbed - and she explored how this illness had come into her life. As she came back “to consciousness” she regained all the shaking and tics. So in this particular case, hypnosis is not only a valid tool of science, it can be a valid tool of medicine. If I had her affliction, I’d spend part of every day doing a hypnosis session to bring it under control.

It's amazing how many people have told me (very matter of factly!) that there is no such thing as hypnosis. Usually, people say it's not real because it's one of the follow: Some people think it's all acting.Some people say it's placebo.Some people think that a hypnotised subject is just 'trying to please the hypnotist'.I agree that all of these are a factor in many cases, but I also believe that hypnosis is definitely real. Here's why... The first person I ever hypnotised When I was 18, back in 1992, I was crazy about hypnosis. I studied it religiously but I was too scared to try it, and I wasn't even sure if I actually believed it. But I knew enough about hypnotic induction scripts to give it a go. So when my sister's friend Mark saw me reading a book on hypnosis and asked me if I would hypnotise him I decided it was time to find out once and for all if it really was real. I used a basic progressive relaxation induction and Mark seemed to be responding well. To begin I gave him some really simple suggestions. The kind of stuff you might expect to see at a cheesy stage hypnosis show, and he did everything exactly as instructed. Of course, I had no way of knowing if it was really genuine or if he was just playing along. I actually started to feel like a bit of an idiot and expected him to suddenly start laughing at me, but he didn't. Instead, something amazing happened.... Something amazing happened that proved hypnosis is real! I gave Mark the suggestion that he was getting colder and colder. Almost immediately he started to shiver. He was wearing a short sleeved top so I could see his bare arms and within seconds all of the tiny hairs on his arms stood on end and he got goosebumps!  I told Mark it was getting cold and he got Goosebumps!For me this proved that hypnosis is real! WOW!!! I couldn't believe it. You can't fake goosebumps! This was the real deal. Mark was actually having a physical reaction to my suggestion. I was chuffed to bits!!! Then I switched from cold to hot and the tiny hairs all lay back down and the goosebumps vanished immediately. He started breathing heavily and pulling at his top around his neck. His face flushed red and within seconds there were beads of sweat running down his face. That moment was a turning point in my life. It was all the confirmation I needed that hypnosis is indeed real. You simply can't fake such physical reactions no matter how much you want to 'please the hypnotist'. Before that moment I'd been obsessed with hypnosis. I had studied everything I could get my hands on about the subject. I'd even volunteered for stage hypnotic shows to see if the hypnotist whispered secret instructions to me during the induction. But seeing Marks reaction kicked my obsession up to a whole new level. I became a hypnojunky! Within a year of that first induction experience I was doing stage hypnotic shows in pubs and clubs around my local town. I later ventured into hypnotherapy and ran a very successful clinic from my home and over time I refined my skills and started to teach others how to hypnotise.

Hypnosis is an actual phenomenon. I've never heard of someone being victimized by a hypnotist, but I suppose it could happen. And, law enforcement use of hypnosis is common.Forensic/Investigative HypnosisD. L. Robb, Ph.D.  Hypnosis has been defined as a sustained receptive and intensely focused response to a signal, while diminishing peripheral awareness (Pinizotto, 1989), “facilitated induction of focused attention” (Gravitz, as cited in Kennedy, 2011, n.p.), and, “as an altered state of consciousness, characterized by heightened compliance with suggestion and extreme focused attention” (Raz & Shapiro, 2002, p. 85). Modern use of hypnosis began with Franz Mesmer in the 18th century, and the next prominent practitioner was Sigmund Freud in 1880, who documented use of clinical hypnosis in Studies in Histeriawith Joseph Breuer. “Common false theories continue to associate hypnosis with mysticism, loss of autonomy, and mind control” (p. 86). A definition offered by the Society of Psychological Hypnosis of the American Psychological Association, (2014, p. 4) indicates that: “Hypnosis is a procedure involving cognitive processes [like imagination] in which a subject is guided by a hypnotist to respond to suggestions for changes in sensations, perceptions, thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.”Brain imaging studies have shown hypnosis consists of neurophysiological  mechanisms in the prefrontal cortex and in other areas controlling executive attention (Raz & Shapiro). Responsive subjects show brain activation indicating that hypnosis is more than social compliance or role playing with regard to auditory perceptions, visual perceptions, and posthypnotic suggestions.Hypnosis is not universally effective, although even lower levels of hypnotic trance can lead to beneficial results clinically. In the U.S., 10 percent of the population is considered to be non-hypnotizable, with those amenable to hypnosis varying in depth of hypnotic trance between mild and deep (Gafner & Benson, 2003). The best subjects are generally children from age 5, with decreasing susceptibility to hypnosis beyond age 21 (Boulch, n.d.). Positive motivation is essential for optimal results; and, a negative attitude, illness, or post trauma circumstances will generally lead to poor hypnotic outcomes (Raz & Shapiro). Raz and Shapiro also indicated that neuroimaging indicates that the volume and structure of thenerve fibers that carry motor, sensory, and cognitive information between the left and right brain hemispheres can be correlated to attention and inhibitory processing, as well as hypnotizability. Dr. David Eagleman (2011), who directs the Laboratory for Perception and Action and the Initiative on Neuroscience and Law, Baylor College of Medicine has stated that “implicit memory systems are fundamentally separate from explicit memory systems: even when the second one has lost the data the former one has a lock on it” (p.64). Moreover, implicit associations (subconscious thoughts) are generally not accessible to conscious thought.Forensic hypnosis is primarily concerned with hypermnesia, the ability to recover lost memories (Boulch). The reliability of hypnotically recalled information is directly related to the evidence that the hypnotist has not influenced the person being hypnotized. In spite of the Rock v. Arkansas (1987) decision, in which the Supreme Court held that states may not exclude all testimony of a defendant aided or refreshed by hypnosis, as doing so would be a violation of a defendant’s constitutional rights, many jurisdictions prohibit testimony on memories obtained during or following hypnosis. And, a few states and some federal circuits deal with hypnosis on a case-by-case basis (Webert, 2003). Where potentially allowed in court, probative (admissible as testimony) or prejudicial determinations are made based on procedural safeguards in place during the hypnotic session, the totality of the circumstances (Martin, 2003).Four potentially negative outcomes from hypnosis have been identified (Webert, 2003; Howell, 2013). First, there is an increased susceptibility to suggestion while hypnotized; and second, there may be a loss of critical judgment and/or desire to please the hypnotist, or the perception that the hypnosis process will provide the proper answer. This can be intentional or unintentional. Third is “confabulation,” the filling of memory gaps, a concept somewhat analogous to the first outcome, except that confabulation occurs subconsciously within the subject. The fourth is memory hardening, wherein confidence of the hypnotically recalled information is enhanced, possibly in error. These improper outcomes detract from accurate testimony and accurate evaluation of testimony by a jury.Howell (2013) identified ten procedural safeguards the hypnotist must comply with in order to adhere to court admissibility requirements, as dictated by Texas case law as derived from Zani v. State:1.   An acceptable level of training in clinical and forensic hypnosis;2.   Independence from assigned investigators, prosecutors, and defense attorneys;3.   Records indicating case information known prior to the session;4.   Records of written or recorded accounts of case information known by the subject prior to the session;5.   Recordings (video and audio) of all contacts between the hypnotist and the subject;6.   Records of all those present at any time during the session and where conducted;7.   Appropriate induction and memory retrieval techniques;8.   Appropriate application in the type of memory being retrieved;9.   Records of evidence corroborating hypnotically retrieved testimony; and,10. Evidence of presence or absence of suggestive or leading questions, whether overt or subtle.“With the knowledge of memory and hypnosis that is available, the cautious use of hypnosis may be of great importance to the field of forensic investigation,” according to Pinizotto,  a forensic psychologist formerly with the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s Behavioral Science Unit (BSU) (1989, p. 327). This sentiment has been repeated elsewhere (Martin, 2003; Webert, 2003). Hypnotically enhanced memory is assured to be acceptable to the extent that information so obtained can be corroborated, thereby negating the need for testimony at trial (Webert, 2003).Major federal investigative agencies have recognized the potential investigative benefits of hypnosis, and have been consulting since 1979 to develop a “Federal Model” for forensic hypnosis, indicated by Kennedy, a psychologist at the FBI's BSU ( 2011). Recognizing that there is no inherent validity in hypnotically enhanced memory, independent corroboration is necessary. Therefore, careful administrative approval procedures are required in advance (including Attorney General approval for Department of Justice agencies), as are specific interview procedures. The entire hypnotic session is videotaped, and the hypnosis is to be conducted by a mental health professional in the presence the case agent or agency coordinator. The process and potential problems (e.g., abreaction [emotion induced by reliving trauma]) are to be explained to the witness, and informed consent obtained. And, other specifics are detailed in their protocol.  The above elements are consistent with the processes of investigative hypnosis (Reiser, 1980), in that hypnosis merely introduces the element of a “signal from another …, which activates a capacity for a shift of awareness in the subject that permits a more intensive concentration upon a designated goal” (Speigel, 1972, p. 25).As an analogy, the Cognitive Interview (CI) was developed for use with cooperative adults when a crime has been documented (Poole & Lamb, 1998). A deficiency of CI is that it is of little value in cases of false reporting. The CI interview incorporates contextual re-creation, recall of all senses (sight, sound, and smell, etc.), and varied temporal sequencing (first to last and last to first), guided imagery, and repetition. Moreover, Raz and Shapiro (2002) indicated that therapists engage in hypnosis-like activities in common counseling sessions. There is also evidence from brain imaging to indicate similarities between hypnosis, meditation, prayer, and attentive play or study. Let us be clear on what hypnosis is and what it is not. Hypnosis is real but it is not at all manipulating brain with an extreme manipulation. What Hypnosis is!Hypnosis is a unique and powerful mental state that is distinct from our  normal waking  and sleep states. The precise definition of hypnosis is a  hotly debated subject, even among hypnotists, though there are some  characteristics that are commonly agreed upon. Two of these  are  narrowed focus and increased suggestibility.  Narrowly focused attention - While in hypnosis it is  easy to simply 'forget' about the outside world. Stray thoughts and  mental chatter are reduced or turned off completely and body awareness  is similarly reduced or forgotten. Subjects retaining a body awareness  usually describe the sensation with descriptions such as very pleasant,  euphoric, tingly,floating, light or heavy. Increased suggestibility - Increased suggestibility  means that suggestions made during hypnosis, either by a hypnotist or  through self-hypnosis, will have a greater impact than if they were made  during normal waking consciousness. This does not mean that any suggestion  made will be mechanically obeyed.  It is widely accepted that in order for hypnotic suggestions to take  hold they must be in agreement with the individual's own moral code.  Furthermore these suggestions should be therapeutically well-formed,  meaning that they are crafted for maximum effect by using language that  is best suited to the subject's own communication style. What Hypnosis is not!There are many common fears and misconceptions  about hypnosis popularized by books and movies, or by having seen or  heard about outlandish behavior induced by a stage hypnotist. The most  common fears are centered around losing control over one's own mind,  revealing private information or being made to take inappropriate  actions. Through the use of drugs and aggressive brainwashing techniques  this may be possible, however it is not at all possible with hypnosis.   All hypnosis is self-hypnosis and it's much more  accurate to think of the hypnotist as a coach or tour guide rather than  as a master and commander. Entering hypnosis is a completely voluntary  process that takes the full cooperation of the subject. People are often  surprised, sometimes even disappointed, after their first hypnosis  session if they were expecting an overpowering or mind-blowing  experience. While these mental states are possible it usually takes a  few sessions for most people to enter deep hypnosis. Being in a state of hypnosis does not in any way circumvent our normal  sense of values. To the contrary, as hypnosis is a state of deep focus  and powerful inner awareness it is much more likely to promote an even  stronger sense of self and adherence to one's personal values. This is  how hypnosis can be so effective in achieving goals such as weight loss  or quitting smoking, by putting us intimately in touch with our core  beliefs and desires. Throughout the day we naturally enter states of hypnosis in various  ways. Also, as we are falling asleep or waking up we briefly pass  through states that are similar to  hypnosis.  In summation, hypnosis is a natural state of mind and a  powerful tool that may help us achieve our goals, it may not be used to  harm or compromise us.  Source: Hypnosis Facts & Myths

State theorists claim that hypnotic suggestions induce an altered state of consciousness or hypnotic trance in which highly suggestible people are willing to obey the hypnotist and behave in uncharacteristic ways, such as remembering forgotten events, forgetting what they have just done and obeying post-hypnotic suggestions to perform some embarrassing action when given a cue. Non-state theorists claim that all these effects are better explained by role playing and suggestibility. So there is plenty of scientific research but no agreement as to the best explanation.
